title: Lupinus lepidus
text:
Lupinus lepidus, the Pacific lupine, prairie lupine or dwarf lupine is a <a href="perennial%20plant">perennial</a> <a href="herbaceous%20plant">herbaceous plant</a> in the pea family (<a href="Fabaceae">Fabaceae</a>) <a href="endemism">endemic</a> to western <a href="North%20America">North America</a>. Many varieties have been described, several of which are considered separate species by some authorities.
Habitat and range.
In western North America, "Lupinus lepidus" may be found in open areas from low prairie, open <a href="Montane%20ecology">montane forest</a>, to the <a href="Alpine%20plant">alpine</a>. Although rare in <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a>, its range extends south from <a href="Alaska">Alaska</a> to southern <a href="California">California</a> and eastward to the <a href="Rocky%20Mountains">Rocky Mountains</a>. In California, it is mainly a species of meadows and areas that are moist during the spring growing season in the <a href="Sierra%20Nevada">Sierra Nevada</a> mountain range, from .
Description.
"Lupinus lepidus" is a small hairy perennial that reaches . Palmately compound leaves extend up the stem, but most are <a href="Basal%20%28anatomy%29">basal</a>. The inflorescence is a dense spike-like raceme, with pink, purple, or blue flowers that often have a yellowish spot. The plant blooms from mid-April through August, depending on elevation and habitat. The fruit is a pod containing multiple seeds.
